course.subject: MECH
course.name: Fluid Mechanics
course.description: Fundamental concepts; hydrostatics; integral and differential equations of fluid flows; conservation of mass, momentum and energy; dimensional analysis; pipe flow; channel flow and boundary layers.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 2011 OR MATH 2023) AND MECH 2310
course.exclusions: CENG 2220, CIVL 2510, MATH 4326

reviews.author: Jacky 01
reviews.title: 比較難既mech course
reviews.comment_content: 呢個係比較難既一科，一個有9個chapter，涉及partial derivative同埋一的math 2011既野，特別係第5,6課，因此呢兩課最難。呢課要真係理解佢既原理先得，唔可以淨係代公式咁簡單。
reviews.comment_teaching: 佢上堂雖然講得都算幾清楚， 但佢會講好多如何得到條公式既方法，當中涉及好多calculus，但其實又唔洗考，卻又同的要考既混埋一起，搞唔清楚邊的係重點。但的lecture notes寫得好差，幾乎得數字冇文字，你都唔知講咩。如果你想走堂，淨係溫lecture notes既話，係冇可能，因為你根本睇唔明。的lecture notes要聽佢上堂講先明。不過好彩有lecture video，只不過唔係canvas，而係email send條 link比你。但其實都唔係好夠，唔明最好再上YouTube自己睇。Tutorial的notes就幾好，包括左的重點，因此強烈建議溫tutorial notes。
reviews.comment_grading:
因為呢科內容比較難，因此佢出題出得算比較直接，唔算好深，如果你明的原理就好易做。但因為好多人都睇唔明lecture notes，根本搞唔明的原理，因此mean都唔算高。
Homework 10%
Mid-term 40%
Final exam 50%
     我今年既mid-term出得好簡單，一共四條題目，有兩題係照出homework，其中一題係連題目既數字都冇改，同homework一模一樣。另外一題係出2008年既past paper第一題，答案甚至一樣，只不過問得唔同。仲有一題係past tutorial。因此我拎95/100， mean大概60幾。final就難好多，佢會問的上堂有講但lecture notes冇寫出來既野，最後冇出分，但肯定唔過90。

reviews.comment_workload: 每個chapter都有一份功課，只不過我果時最後教果課既功課唔洗交，因此係8份功課，一般係教完果課之後下一個星期五交。其實淨係以呢科來講workload唔算大，但mech其他科都差唔多每星期有一份功課，因此加加埋都差唔多一個星期平均有4份功課，所以感覺都幾chur下。

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: Hard Content, Easy Assessments, Good Grade
reviews.comment_content:
The course contents can be broadly categorized into 3 groups of chapters:

Group A:
1. Basic Properties of Fluid (including introduction on viscosity)
2. Fluid Statics
3. Bernoulli Equation
Group B*:
4. Kinematics of Fluid Motion (including Reynolds Transport Theorem)
5. Flow Analysis Using Control Volume
-----Midterm quiz/exam-----
Group B (con't):
6. Flow Analysis Using Differential Methods
Group C:
8. Pipe Flow
9. Forces on Submerged Bodies

As indicated from the prerequisites, multivariable and vector calculus is an integral part of MECH2210. This is especially true when it comes to the Group B chapters, in which the derivation of theorems include tons of them. That said, as the homework and exam questions are generally easy, you won't see those kind of nightmare questions involving very complex functions similar to your MATH2011 finals.

Professor Li said that the course's difficulty was similar to a bell curve: the Group B chapters are of the most difficult ones, while the Group A and C ones are relatively simple. In fact, as the course contents taught in Group B chapters are so overpowered/difficult, their applications are relatively simple. Lot's of cancellations are often required to reduce theorems into simpler forms in assignment and exam questions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Despite his heavy Chinese accent, Professor Li did teach well during lectures. Most of his lessons involved doing mathematical proofs about various theorems. While some students may find such teaching method boring, personally I find understanding and digesting mathematical proofs rather mentally stimulating (perhaps accustomed by Professor Rhea Liem's teaching during MECH1907).

One of the pros of Professor Li is that he included relevant videos on his lectures, which made abstract concepts more understandable to us. While normally these are to be done by TAs in fact-to-face lectures, videos do provide us a good alternative during special periods. Professional experiences were also mentioned in lectures, such as how his colleagues tried to apply a 2D theorem on a 3D fluid flow.

Regarding the TAs, Wang Yixiang is competent and helpful. Concepts and problem-solving skills are explained well on his tutorials. Despite occasional delays, he provided comprehensive and graphical replies to my homework questions sent by email. Liu Biyuan, the other TA, also offered satisfactory tutorials, although one time when I asked about homework questions, she just threw me with the suggested solutions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 10% (Given to everyone)
Midterm: 35% (85/100, Mean 71.46/100, Median: 75/100, SD: 22.86)
Final: 45% (Never released, but markings by TA can be seen before the course page was deleted)

The assignments are submitted on a voluntary basis, and at the end everyone gets the 10% marks. That said, you receive rather detailed feedbacks from the TA (mainly done by Wang Yixiang), which definitely helps with your learning and better prepares you for exam (at least you don't need to cram all questions before the last lectures).

Instead of exams, Professor Li called them "quizzes" and conducted them in class (basically exam in another name). For the midterm, 2 of the questions are copied homework questions, with one of them copied without numerical value change.

The final is of another format though. There are 2 conceptual questions, with one of them directly asking contents mentioned on lectures. Apart from these concept questions, all other exam questions are rather simple, and are of the difficulty of assignment questions.

Professor Li personally said that if you can finish assignment questions, you should get a satisfactory score in quizzes (exam).

At the end I get an A+ for MECH2210. Note that Professor Redonnet in the other lecture session has different grading. If you desire a good grade, you should seriously consider enrolling in Professor Li's class.
reviews.comment_workload:
All assignments were given at the beginning of the course, which if starting from the end of a chapter, will have approximately one week for us to complete. The assignments are generally of the difficulty of our limited lecture examples, and generally, nothing more difficult will appear on exams.

Tutorials were given on a weekly basis, in which assignment solutions are released and explained in class. The TAs also prepared sufficient examples for us to try on, which compensated the relative lack of examples during lectures.

reviews.comment_teaching: 好無聊，我基本上冇咩上過佢堂，即使上堂都冇咩聽書，上堂好多proof，好少example去俾大家消化，但係唔鼓吹大家走堂！免得害左大家！
reviews.comment_grading: 兩個quiz，呢兩個quiz基本上佔90%final grade，淨低10%送俾你，第一個叫midterm quiz，範圍係頭5課，題目有4條你有認真做過下assignment，保底70分，因為頭三條基本上係送，完全就係copy番功課，最尾一條先會有d唔同，但係final quiz就冇呢支歌仔唱，範圍就係midterm quiz之後個d，全部題目都唔同assignment。講返我個grade，意外地好grade，因為我本身都唔算特別勁，midterm quiz 85/100(mean我大膽估計80左右，因為頭三條已經送70分加埋第四條step分差唔多)，final quiz冇公佈，final grade A-。
reviews.comment_workload: 可以係0 workload，如果你唔想做assignment，你可以唔做，而且你都可以攞到嗰10%，btw我份份都有做。起初個professor就已經講左你抄答案，交份滿分功課冇咩意思，想學嘢就做啦，冇咩所謂。

reviews.author: bbcccc
reviews.comment_content: Fluid Statics, Fluids in Motion (Bernoulli equation), Kinematics of Fluid Motion (The Reynolds transport theorem), Flow analysis using control volume, Differential methods, Pipe Flows, External Flows, Advances in wall-bounded turbulence modelling.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For the lecture, although in the first few lessons, he is teaching quite fast. However, he adjusted his teaching pace afterward. Overall, Prof, Fu has an appropriate teaching pace and detailed explanation of some complex derivations. He is willing to answer the questions and gives enough examples.

However, following the mid-term, the assignment was issued at an unsteady pace, with just one assignment for a few weeks and the last two assignments due on the same day. reviews.author: SamuelLee
reviews.title: New prof this sem
reviews.comment_content: Fluid statics, Bernouli equation, kinematics, flow analysis with control volumes and differential methods, pipe flow, lift and drag. The middle part is the hardest because the derivations are super complex, especially differential methods need to remember so many equations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In his first semester teaching the course, Prof Fu was rushing at the start of the semester, which made us hard to understand the content. This increased our workload, and he kept giving out assignments quickly because of this teaching pace. However, he improved after the midterm, giving more examples and taught at a slower pace, especially for differential methods.

The TA this semester is Anjia Ying. He answered my questions quite quickly and went through a lot of examples with us in the tutorial sessions.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% homework (I bombed one with 68, the rest all 85-90)
40% midterm (mean - 69.1, I got 72)
50% final (not released)

Final grade - B

As a student who only got a C+ in math2011, it was almost impossible for me to understand the definitions in chapter 6, which the professor said is the most important. So, all credit goes to God for this grade. I would have gotten a D without his power entrusted by me, as I lost all hope after the midterm exam.
reviews.comment_workload: In the first half of the semester, there was an assignment every week. But there was only one assignment in quite a few weeks after the midterm, and the last two assignments were released together. It could be better if the assignments can be distributed evenly according to date.

reviews.comment_content: Viscosity, Bernoulli Equation and application, laminar & turbulent flows, differential method in fluid mechanics, fluid dynamics. Interesting, but TOO MUCH. Combines with online lecture, I have to say I just learned some shallow knowledge. But that is not the prof/TA's fault, Ami virus mainly.. people just become lazier during the pandemic.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof has a rather quick pace, so you can easily get distracted once you find yourself behind the progress. But he does explain things well and is passionate, willing to help. TAs will assign complicated questions to you, which are actually not tested in final. I think prof intended to lower the difficulty of final so that most people can pass.
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm exam is a bonus, which means actually there are two grading schemes: hw-mt-final: 2/3/5 and hw-final 2/8, I ASSUME. mt is completely conceptual MCs, has nothing to do with calculation but still kind of intractable. Thanks to Google I scored 36/40. Highest is 38/40 and so prof kindly set 38 as full mark. Same technique is also applied to final exam, which has easier questions compared to hw problems (very advanced calculation problems). I made some interesting assumptions in the final exam, solved all three problems rather easily but screwed up half of assignments.. ended with an A. To be honest I think I almost didn't learn this course...shameful, because stay in your home is just too damn cosy. So I thanked prof. Redonnet very much for giving me a good grade..
reviews.comment_workload: Light. Assignment answers can be found on internet.

reviews.author: Guess who I am
reviews.title: One of the best professors in teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1. Introduction
Chapter 2. Fluid Statics
Chapter 3. Fluids in Motions
Chapter 4. Kinematics of Fluid Motion
Chapter 5. Flow analysis using C.V.
Midterm
Chapter 6. Differential methods
Chapter 8. Pipe Flows
Chapter 9. External Flows and Introduction to Nanofluids
Final
Each chapter takes around 2 to 3 classes to finish except Chapter 6 which takes nearly 3 weeks.
P.S. knowledge of multivaraible calculus is widely applied in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear teaching. Once you have had a solid multivaribale calculus background, the class is quite easy to follow. There are lots of formula derivation and honestly I find it nessary though it would not be included in the exam, as it tells you under what conditions can each formula be applied when solving questions in both homeworks and exams. The PPT is full of equations without comments but during the class they will be popped up on the screen line by line, indicating where the professor is talking about right now.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite decent. Professor Li has said that he wants students to learn the knowledge rather than focusing on the grade. But still you need to review diligently before the exam and be clear about how each formula is generally derived and how they work. I got full mark in the midterm, worked fine in the final and got A+. We are acknowledged the curve of the midterm and nearly 30 percent of students can get A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Every chapter has a homework and each one contains 3 questions around, so overall it's not a heavy-workloaded course.
